Award.AbstractNarration: Crop yield, responses to high CO2 in the atmosphere, and other aspects of plant growth are partially limited and regulated by the transport of nutrients from leaves to distant plants parts, such as roots and grain. The first step in this process, and an important control point, involves loading sugar and other nutrients into the long-distance transport tissue, the phloem. To date, two phloem-loading mechanisms are known, both of which require metabolic energy. In this project the investigators suggest that there is a third mechanism that does not require energy, one that may be used by as many as half of all flowering plants, especially trees. This could explain why some trees are able to use additional atmospheric CO2 without feedback inhibition, which limits growth of herbaceous crop plants under these conditions. The hypothesis will be tested by genetically engineering poplar trees to inhibit active phloem loading. The prediction is that, although such inhibitory treatments severely retard the growth of plants that load actively, they will have little, if any, effect on poplar. Methods of altering transport through the fine pores that connect plant cells, and serve as conducting channels for virus movement, will also be explored. Broader impacts include, 1) testing and potentially restructuring a key tenet of plant nutrient transport, namely that energy is required to load the phloem in preparation for export; 2) determining how some plants use additional CO2 more effectively than others; and 3) potentially developing a transgenic method of restricting virus movement across specific cellular interfaces. Educational broader impacts include training exceptional undergraduates for careers in science, leading a prison education program, teaching a large introductory biology course for non-biology majors, and writing scientific articles for the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Agricultural yield is determined by the growth efficiency of harvested tissues, such as wood, grain or fruit. The food for this growth, primarily sucrose, is generated in leaves by photosynthesis. Sucrose and other compounds are then loaded into the phloem for long-distance transport to growing tissues. To a large extent, the efficiency and specificity of nutrient transport, and hence yield, is determined by the phloem loading mechanism. In this grant period we challenged fundamental assumptions about phloem loading as it pertains to poplar, an economically important and highly productive tree species. It has been generally assumed that phloem loading always requires energy, that transporter proteins on the phloem plasma membranes conduct sucrose into the phloem, and that the exceptionally high internal phloem pressure generated by energetically active loading is necessary to drive long-distance transport. In our studies we produced transgenic poplar with invertase, a sucrose cleavage enzyme, in the cell walls. Invertase in this location inhibits loading if transporters are required. Our transgenic poplar trees grew normally. Alfalfa plants, which are known to load via transporters, were also transformed by the same procedure, as controls, and, as expected, they were greatly retarded in their growth. These results provide compelling proof that sucrose simply diffuses into the phloem in poplar through plasmodesmata, the pores that connect plant cells. Literature data on plasmodesmatal frequencies suggest that this passive loading mechanism is widespread in tree species. Additional results demonstrated that hexoses in the cell wall space make poplar especially prone to the hypersensitive response, adding to data that these simple sugars play an important role in the defensive response to pathogens.

Broader Impacts:

The almost total emphasis on transporter-mediated loading by the phloem community has created the false assumptions that all materials that enter the phloem do so via transporters and that the exceptionally high pressure generated by transporter-mediated loading is necessary for long-distance phloem transport. Contrary to these assumptions, our data on passive loading through plasmodesmata demonstrates that essentially all molecules small enough to pass through these intercellular pores can enter the phloem in poplar, thus challenging long-held notions about the selectivity of nutrient transport. Also, the absence of active loading in trees, which have far longer transport distances than herbs, calls into question the need for excessive pressure to drive phloem transport and summons us to think more deeply about the true advantages this pressure provides to plants. During the course of this work one postdoctoral fellow (Cankui Zhang), two visiting PhD students (Lin Chen, Xin Li) and two undergraduates (David Liu, Wesley Chao) were supported, or partially supported. Cankui Zhang is currently an Assistant Professor in the Agronomy Department at Purdue University and continues his studies in plant biology. The PI participated heavily in prison education (Cornell Prison Education Program), teaching undergraduate biology and using many examples from his NSF-supported research. This is an important component of the education of a severely underrepresented group, which improves their lives in prison, fosters positive interactions in the prison population, provides a foundation for positive thinking and provides academic prerequisites for further educational achievements upon release. This is also hugely beneficial in terms of taxpayers dollars since prisoners who are released from our program and others like it have exceptionally low recidivism rates.
